narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the history of human rights in political theory as well as in the practice of international law-making, and gained background context on a wide variety of human rights issues and debates. I complicated and strengthened my notion of "human rights" which, prior to taking this course, had existed in my mind as a somewhat meaningless blanket phrase within political debates.
I learned the history and development of human rights legislation and theory, as well as many of the current debates surrounding human rights discourse in the digital age.

History and politics of human rights; how to view human rights through a nuanced and critical eye; why different cultures and societies take different perspectives on human rights; how human rights have gone from being male-centric to inclusive of multiple populations (ex., women, children, LGBT people)
I learned a lot about how complex the notion of human rights is. The course provided a great basis for understanding the significance and theories of human rights .

I learned a LOT about, as the class entails in its name, the theories, practices, and politics of human rights. Really, I learned a lot about the human rights framework as it exists today. If this interests you, then the class will be valuable to you!

I definitely learned a lot. This course went over a ton of information in a very short amount of time. I was exposed to a lot of literature about human rights from a wide range of perspectives and time periods and gave me the opportunity to begin to understand the theories and applications of human rights.
I have learned to think about traditional and current political issues faced globally, in an entirely critical way.
An overview of relevant human rights issues and frameworks
History of human rights theory, human rights application, international human rights jurisdiction

History of human rights and human rights enforcements, challenges to human rights from both the left and right, alternative (non-Western) perspectives, various philosophical foundations of human rights, methods of deploying human rights  rhetoric for advocacy, limitations to human rights

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths; Ryan was a very clear lecturer and is good at elucidating very complex concepts in a digestible way. This class does a great job covering a VAST amount of ground in terms of human rights theory/history and lectures felt structured in a very intentional way which is more than I can say for many Yale classes tbh 
weaknesses: i honestly think it's hard to feel completely engaged in a class SO broad sometimes, it can feel like there is nothing particular to grasp onto and focus on. we did have discussions sometimes but i think this class could have benefited from that more because the "discussion/debate" format can draw out the issues that are most complex and pressing within human rights. Also I wish there had been a bit more guidance on the final paper

This course was a great introduction to the field, especially for someone who had not studied the subject before. Professor Thoreson is very knowledgeable, understanding, and is genuinely excited about the topics in the course. I liked the weekly reading response assignments and enjoyed writing the final paper.

Strengths: Professor Thoreson and the TFs were GREAT!!!; human rights is a super interesting topic; the class and syllabus were excellently organized; weekly reading load was very manageable; final paper offered a great opportunity for academic explanation

Weaknesses: weekly reading responses were leniently grades, but not very constructive
Both the lectures and discussion sections for this class were really really thoughtfully put together, delivered, and always were so highly engaging.

We didn't have the opportunity to go in-depth with some of the more interesting subjects, but I think it was a really good survey course to gain a foundational understanding of human rights. The workload was very low, just discussion responses and a final paper, but I really enjoyed the course overall.

The course was strong because it covered topics that were interesting, and the professor and the teaching assistant had the class engage at all times. Itwas never just them speaking to us without inviting feedback.

I think 45% weight for the final paper is a bit much, as there was relatively little guidance for it built into the class. Of course, the professor and TA's were very helpful when students reached out.

Strengths: wide scope of material covered, engaging discussions

Weaknesses: low student engagement, little engagement with readings, little feedback on weekly responses

Strengths:
- Great variety of reading for a very comprehensive perspective of human rights
- Discussion sections were very engaging

Weaknesses:
- Low student engagement overall (definitely not the professors fault, just a general trend)
- Comparatively, larger sections were much less engaging than smaller ones (I had to attend a smaller one a few times out of necessity). Each student in smaller section presented their own unique perspective on the weeks issues in their response paper, whereas large section was much more general and less personalized.
- I didnt feel like I learned too much about the UN bureaucracy overall, and I would have appreciated an introduction to this topic earlier on

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: i thought the course practices made sense; zoom is always fatiguing and i don't know if there's any way out of that, but the team for this class was kind and understanding regarding assignments and even made switches in the middle of the semester to accommodate for students facing mental health struggles during this difficult year, which was deeply appreciated.
The virtual sections were difficult at times, but the class got used to it overtime. The lectures felt like normal in person lectures.

I think it was very helpful to break into smaller discussion sessions on a day separate from the main lecture. it gave us time to think about what was discussed and come up with questions we would have.
No covid-specific practices, although the professor did incorporate covid-related ethical questions and human rights issues into the course, which was an intellectually rewarding move.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course if you're okay with seeking breadth over depth; know that you likely won't come away with a deep understanding of any particular human rights issues but rather with a sense of  how political theory grounds human rights/ some of the treaties and international bodies that carry out human rights across many issues. To me this content could sometimes be a little dry but there were definitely several modules that have stuck with me and I think the class was as good as it could be for an intro-style class
Yes, this is a great introduction to a very interesting and important topic! Please consider even if you are not in the human rights program, because I learned so much.

Yes!! Absolutely!! This class had fairly chill vibes, and will teach you + change your perspective on the world so much! 
(Im not even a human rights scholar and still really enjoyed it!)
Yes if you are very interested in human rights, if not it is not a must.

I would recommend this course to anyone who has an interest in human rights. It definitely gave me the language and the theories to better talk about human rights, a term that is often thrown around but never clearly defined. I think that it was incredibly interesting to me and I really enjoyed learning about it, especially because my section was so good and gave me the opportunity to work through my thoughts and concerns.
Yes, absolutely! Even if the student is not going to be a political science major, it was very helpful in looking at global issues that would overflow into other areas/curricula.
Yes! It is a gateway course, so there's no splitting the atom going on, but you get to talk about wide ranging issues, and the assignments force you to develop opinions on them. Very good.
I would recommend this course as a great survey of various human rights traditions.
Yes. It provides a very good introduction to what human rights are/ought to be and political philosophy in general.
